awd_titl_txt: EAGER: JOINT CRYO NEUTRON/X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY OF RNA AND RNA-PROTEIN INTERACTIONS
awd_abstract_narration:
The ribose 2'-hydroxyl group (2'-OH) is the key chemical difference between RNA and DNA. Their divergent characteristics, including structure, stability, function and activity, can be attributed to various degrees to the presence of the 2'-OH in RNA and its absence in DNA. The 2'-OH affects the sugar conformational equilibrium and thereby the geometry of paired RNA strands, and ultimately the much-expanded 3D fold-space of RNA compared to DNA. The 2'-OH is the only hydrogen bond donor in the nucleic acid backbone and results in increased RNA hydration and thermodynamic stability relative to DNA. Moreover, the 2'-OH acts as nucleophile in RNA splicing reactions and ribozyme-catalyzed phosphodiester cleavage. Structural biology has ignored the 2'-OH hydrogen/orientation, owing to technical limitations of X-ray crystallography (XC) and challenges to solution studies such as rapid exchange. Neutron crystallography (NC) reveals the locations of hydrogen atoms (2H, deuterium or D) in biomacromolecules. In the project joint cryo-NC/XC will be used on several RNA targets to assess: (i) The importance of the 2'-OH in RNA’s expansive fold space, (ii) How binding proteins might influence 2'-OH orientation to sculpt the RNA backbone, and (iii) Differences in 2'- and 3'-OH orientations in 5'-3' and 5'-2' linked RNAs, respectively, that might explain the latter’s demise in nature. The rigorous, combined NC/XC approach will produce improved models of water structure and a better understanding of nucleic acid structure, function and interactions with binding proteins. The project work will ultimately enable refined theoretical treatments of macromolecules and hydration, e.g., by molecular dynamics simulations. Structural refinements and data science aspects of this research, including PDB searches and large-scale analysis of pucker modes provide ideal projects for high-school students/undergraduates as part of Vanderbilt’s Aspirnaut program.

Neutron crystallography (NC) reveals the locations of hydrogen atoms (2H, deuterium or D) in biomacromolecules. Conversely, X-ray crystallography (XC) cannot pinpoint H atoms even at high resolution. Cryo NC also establishes the orientations of first- and higher-shell D2O. However, NC research has remained high-risk/-impact, owing to the need for large crystals, perdeuterated samples and limited access to beamlines. Recently the PI applied cryo NC for the first time to an RNA structure using state-of the-art instrumentation at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL). Cryo NC uncovered roles of ribose hydroxyls (2'-OHs) in stabilizing non-canonical backbone geometries, a structural correlation between 2'-OH orientation and sugar pucker, and a 6:1 preference of the 2'-OH to act as H-bond donor rather than acceptor. These insights lead to hypotheses in regard to: (i) The importance of the 2'-OH moiety in RNA’s expanded fold space relative to DNA (ii) How binding proteins might influence 2'-OH orientation and flip the ribose pucker to sculpt the RNA backbone geometry, and (iii) Differences in 2'- and 3'-OH orientations in 5'-3' and 5'-2' linked RNAs, respectively, that may explain the latter’s demise in nature. Water in living systems is omnipresent and is involved in governing folding, geometry, stability, dynamics, function and interactions of proteins and nucleic acids. The rigorous cryo NC/XC approach will produce improved models of water structure, with implications for our understanding of nucleic acid structure, function and interactions with binding proteins. The project work will ultimately enable refined theoretical treatments of macromolecules and hydration by QM-MM and MD simulations.

por.por_cntn:
The ribose 2'-hydroxyl group (2'-OH) is the key chemical difference between RNA and DNA. Their divergent characteristics, including structure, stability, function and activity, can be attributed to various degrees to the presence of the 2'-OH in RNA and its absence in DNA. The 2'-OH affects the sugar conformational equilibrium and thereby the geometry of RNA strands, and ultimately enables the much-expanded 3D fold-space of RNA compared to DNA. The 2'-OH is the only hydrogen bond (H-bond) donor in the nucleic acid backbone and results in increased RNA hydration and thermodynamic stability relative to DNA. Moreover, the 2'-OH acts as nucleophile in RNA splicing reactions and ribozyme-catalyzed phosphodiester cleavage. Structural biology has ignored the 2'-OH hydrogen/orientation, owing to technical limitations of X-ray crystallography (XC) and challenges to solution studies such as rapid exchange. Neutron crystallography (NC) reveals the locations of hydrogen atoms (2H, deuterium or D) in biomacromolecules and especially under cryogenic conditions the orientations of first- and higher-shell D2O.

At the outset we determined the first neutron crystal structure of an RNA, the E. coli 23S rRNA sarcin/ricin loop (SRL) 27mer. We used the Macromolecular Neutron Diffractometer on the Spallation Neutron Source (MaNDi/SNS) at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL, Oak Ridge, Tennessee) to collect diffraction data to ca. 2.1 Å resolution at 110 K. The combined NC/XC structural model of the SRL uncovered roles of 2'-OH in stabilizing non-canonical backbone geometries, a structural correlation between 2'-OH orientation and sugar pucker, and a 6:1 preference of the 2'-OH to act as H-bond donor rather than acceptor. These insights lead to hypotheses with regard to: (i) The importance of the 2'-OH moiety in RNA’s expanded fold space relative to DNA (ii) How binding proteins might influence 2'-OH orientation and flip the ribose pucker to sculpt the backbone geometry to mediate RNA-protein interactions , and (iii) Differences in 2'- and 3'-OH orientations in 5'-3' and 5'-2' linked RNAs, respectively, that may explain the reduced stability of the latter and its demise in nature.

In the first aim, we grew crystals of a size suitable for NC of an RNA dodecamer with G:A mismatch pairs and a viral RNA -1 frameshifting pseudoknot with an unusually short, vertical distance between a water and positively charged cytosine potentially consistent with a water lone pair-nucleobase Pi-system interaction. We initiated data collection experiments on MaNDi/SNS that were delayed owing to the upgrade of the SNS during 2023 and 2024. Experiments with A-form RNA and pseudoknot to gain insight into hydration patterns and water orientations will be pursued in 2025 now that the beamline is back on-line and affording a higher neutron flux. We also studied a classic B-form DNA, the Dickerson-Drew Dodecamer (DDD), with the combined NC/XC approach and were able to collect a 1.9 Å cryo-NC data set on MaNDi/SNS. These data will finally reveal H-bond donor-acceptor patterns in the water structure around DNA and the orientations of waters forming the iconic minor groove spine 45 years after the publication of the DDD structure.

In the second aim, we developed a novel crystallization protocol for complexes between the Argonaute 2 (Ago2) MID domain and nucleotides. Ago2 captures the 5’-terminal phosphate of small interfering RNA (siRNA) and micro-RNA (miRNA) in its MID pocket. Between the first and the second nucleotide, the RNA adopts a sharp turn whereby the first nucleotide exhibits an atypical C2’-endo pucker. Its 2’-OH may interact with the bridging phosphate to stabilize the turn. Efforts to use NC to analyze the orientations of H-bond acceptors and donors around the phosphate were stymied by difficulties to grow crystals of MID with di- and trinucleotides. However, a strategy that links MID and dinucleotide ligands covalently may afford complexes that can be trapped in the crystal and then allow visualization of the precise interaction between bridging phosphate and 2’-OH.

The third aim to analyze the distribution of ribose puckers using a large-scale data set of RNA and RNA-protein complex crystal structures curated in the Protein Data Bank in a resolution-dependent manner is currently underway. It will deliver detailed statistics of the distribution of puckers in individual folds and across thousands of RNA structures. As well this analysis can uncover potential differences between the sugar conformations seen in the structure of an RNA alone and that of the corresponding RNA bound to protein. This could hint at the ability of proteins to use the 2’-OH to sculpt the local RNA backbone and optimize the architecture of the binding interface.

The rigorous, combined NC/XC approach has produced improved models of the water structure around RNA and DNA and will afford a better understanding of nucleic acid structure, function and interactions with binding proteins. Our work will ultimately enable refined theoretical treatments of macromolecules and hydration, e.g., by molecular dynamics simulations.
